intro: Peristylus lacertifer, commonly known as the lizard-leaf plant, is a unique member of the Apiaceae family. It is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves that resemble the skin of a lizard, giving it its common name. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the carrot family. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in temperate regions. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for both horticultural and ecological studies.
